questions.question: Economics deals primarily with the concept of:
options: change.
power
poverty
scarcity
questions.correctAnswer: scarcity

questions.question: Scarcity exists when
options: the price of a good rises.
society can meet the wants of every individual.
there is less of a good or resource available than people wish to have.
there is less than an infinite amount of a resource or good.
questions.correctAnswer: there is less of a good or resource available than people wish to have.

questions.question: Economics is defined as the study of
options: how society manages its scarce resources.
business.
central planning.
government regulation.
questions.correctAnswer: how society manages its scarce resources.

questions.question: A good definition of equity would be
options: efficiency.
eliminating extreme affluence.
fairness.
everyone receiving the same income.
questions.correctAnswer: fairness.

questions.question: When government policies are being designed,
options: increasing efficiency usually results in more equity.
there is usually a tradeoff between equity and efficiency.
equity can usually be achieved without an efficiency loss.
equity and efficiency goals are usually independent of each other.
questions.correctAnswer: there is usually a tradeoff between equity and efficiency.

questions.question: The opportunity cost of an item is
options: what you give up to get that item.
always equal to the dollar value of the item.
always less than the dollar value of the item.
the number of hours needed to earn the money to buy it.
questions.correctAnswer: what you give up to get that item.

questions.question: Ryan spends an hour studying instead of going for a bike ride. The opportunity cost to him of studying is
options: the improvement in his grades from studying for the hour.
the enjoyment and exercise he would have received had he gone for a bike ride.
the difference between the improvement in his grades from studying minus the enjoyment of a bike ride.
zero. Since Ryan chose to study rather than to ride his bike, the value of studying must have been greater than the value of the bike ride.
questions.correctAnswer: the enjoyment and exercise he would have received had he gone for a bike ride.

questions.question: A rational decision maker takes an action only if the
options: marginal benefit is greater than the marginal cost.
average benefit is greater than the average cost.
marginal benefit is less than the marginal cost.
marginal benefit is greater than both the average cost and the marginal cost.
questions.correctAnswer: marginal benefit is greater than the marginal cost.

questions.question: A marginal change is a
options: long-term trend.
change for the worse.
small incremental adjustment.
large, significant adjustment.
questions.correctAnswer: small incremental adjustment.

questions.question: Economists understand that people respond to
options: the wishes of policymakers.
tax breaks, but not tax hikes.
threats more than rewards.
incentives.
questions.correctAnswer: incentives.

questions.question: Which is the most accurate statement about trade?
options: Trade can make every nation better off.
Trade makes some nations better off and others worse off.
Trade helps rich nations and hurts poor nations.
Trading for a good can make a nation better off only if the nation cannot produce that good.
questions.correctAnswer: Trade can make every nation better off.

questions.question: If Canada is better than the United States at producing hockey sticks, but the United States is better than Canada at producing roller blades, the United States should
options: put a quota on the amount of Canadian hockey sticks imported.
subsidize its hockey stick industry so that it can compete with Canadian hockey sticks.
sell roller blades to Canada, and buy Canadian hockey sticks.
impose a tariff on Canadian hockey sticks in order to protect jobs in the U.S. roller blade industry.
questions.correctAnswer: sell roller blades to Canada, and buy Canadian hockey sticks.

questions.question: In a market economy, economic activity is guided by
options: the government.
corporations.
central planners.
prices.
questions.correctAnswer: prices.

questions.question: One advantage market economies have over central planning is that market economies
options: solve the problem of scarcity.
are more efficient.
establish government economic control.
provide an equal distribution of goods and services to consumers.
questions.correctAnswer: are more efficient.

questions.question: The term market failure refers to
options: an unsuccessful advertising campaign.
a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.
a situation in which competition among firms becomes ruthless.
a firm which is forced out of business because of losses.
questions.correctAnswer: a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.

questions.question: An externality is the impact of
options: a person’s actions on that person’s well-being.
society’s decisions on the well-being of society.
one person’s actions on the well-being of a bystander.
society’s decisions on the well-being of one person.
questions.correctAnswer: one person’s actions on the well-being of a bystander.

questions.question: If a copper refinery does NOT bear the entire cost of the smoke it emits, it will
options: emit too much smoke.
emit lower levels of smoke.
emit an acceptable level of smoke.
eliminate all smoke so as to avoid the entire cost of the smoke.
questions.correctAnswer: emit too much smoke.

questions.question: The two best reasons for a government to intervene in a market are to
options: promote equity and to raise revenues.
promote equity and to promote efficiency.
promote efficiency and to raise revenues.
raise revenues and to promote stability.
questions.correctAnswer: promote equity and to promote efficiency.

questions.question: Market power refers to the
options: power of the government to regulate a market.
relative importance of a market to the overall economy.
power of a single person (or small group of people) to unduly influence market prices.
ability of a person or group of people to successfully market new products.
questions.correctAnswer: power of a single person (or small group of people) to unduly influence market prices.

questions.question: The income of a typical worker in a country is most closely linked to which of the following?
options: population
government policies
labor unions
productivity
questions.correctAnswer: productivity

questions.question: Almost all variation in living standards is attributable to differences in countries’
options: population growth rates.
endowments of natural resources.
defense budgets.
productivity.
questions.correctAnswer: productivity.

questions.question: Productivity is defined as the
options: amount of goods and services produced from each hour of a worker’s time.
number of workers required to produce a given amount of goods and services.
amount of labor which can be saved by replacing workers with machines.
actual amount of effort workers put into an hour of working time.
questions.correctAnswer: amount of goods and services produced from each hour of a worker’s time.

questions.question: Inflation is defined as
options: a period of rising productivity in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.
a period of rising income in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of output in the economy.
questions.correctAnswer: an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.

questions.question: Inflation causes
options: productivity to increase.
the value of money to rise.
the value of money to fall.
the government to lower taxes.
questions.correctAnswer: the value of money to fall.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most correct statement about the relationship between inflation and unemployment?
options: In the long run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the long run, reducing inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
questions.correctAnswer: In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.

questions.question: The production possibilities frontier is a
options: map which shows the frontier beyond which agriculture is unprofitable.
map which shows areas of the world in which capitalist production is now possible.
graph that shows the various combinations of output that the economy can possibly produce given the available resources and technology.
graph which shows the various combinations of resources that can be used to produce a given level of output.
questions.correctAnswer: graph that shows the various combinations of output that the economy can possibly produce given the available resources and technology.

questions.question: Which of the following concepts is NOT illustrated by the production possibilities frontier?
options: efficiency
opportunity cost
equity
tradeoffs
questions.correctAnswer: equity

questions.question: On the production possibilities frontier shown, which point or points are possible for this economy to produce?
options: A, B, C, D
A, B, C, F
A, B, C, D, E, F
D
questions.correctAnswer: A, B, C, D

questions.question: On the production possibilities frontier shown, which point or points are inefficient?
options: A, B, C
E, F
B
D
questions.correctAnswer: D

questions.question: The opportunity cost of obtaining more of one good is shown on the production possibilities frontier as the
options: amount of the other good which must be given up.
market price of the additional amount produced.
amount of resources which must be devoted to its production.
number of dollars which must be spent to produce it.
questions.correctAnswer: amount of the other good which must be given up.

questions.question: A production possibilities frontier will be linear and not bowed out if
options: no tradeoffs exist.
the tradeoff between the two goods is always at a constant rate.
the unemployment rate is zero.
resources are allocated efficiently.
questions.correctAnswer: the tradeoff between the two goods is always at a constant rate.

questions.question: In the production possibilities frontier shown, the shift of the frontier from A to B was most likely caused by which of the following?
options: more capital available in the economy
more labor available in the economy
a general technological breakthrough
technological improvement in the production of clothing
questions.correctAnswer: technological improvement in the production of clothing

questions.question: In the production possibilities frontier shown, what is the opportunity cost to society of the movement from point D to point B?
options: 600 pretzels
800 pretzels
250 pretzels
100 pretzels
questions.correctAnswer: 250 pretzels

questions.question: In the production possibilities frontier shown, the movement from point C to point E was most likely caused by
options: an increase in society’s preference for pretzels.
a decrease in society’s preference for potato chips.
unemployment.
a and b
questions.correctAnswer: unemployment.

questions.question: Which of the following would be considered a topic of study in microeconomics?
options: the effect of changes in saving rates on GDP
the impact of minimum-wage laws on employment in the fast-food industry
the impact of monetary policy on the rate of inflation
the effect of tax policy on the rate of economic growth
questions.correctAnswer: the impact of minimum-wage laws on employment in the fast-food industry

questions.question: In the graph shown, the slope of the curve between points A and B is
Since economists are unable to obtain economic data by conducting experiments, they generally must
options: do without data.
use whatever data the world gives them.
select a committee of economists to make up data for all economists to use.
ask policymakers to conduct experiments for them.
questions.correctAnswer: use whatever data the world gives them.

questions.question: Models
options: allow economists to learn how the economy works.
make the economics profession more difficult than necessary.
based on false assumptions cannot be useful to economists.
must include every possible variable in the economy to be useful to economists.
questions.correctAnswer: allow economists to learn how the economy works.

questions.question: When building a model, economists begin by
options: applying for government funding.
conducting controlled experiments in a lab.
making assumptions.
reviewing statistical forecasts.
questions.correctAnswer: making assumptions.

questions.question: In a simple two-sector circular-flow diagram,
options: firms are sellers in the resource market and the product market.
households are sellers in the resource market.
firms are buyers in the product market.
households are buyers in both the resource market and the product market.
questions.correctAnswer: households are sellers in the resource market.

questions.question: In a simple two-sector circular-flow diagram,
options: spending on goods and services flow from firms to households.
goods and services flow from households to firms.
factors of production flow from firms to households.
income from factors of production flows from firms to households.
questions.correctAnswer: income from factors of production flows from firms to households.

questions.question: In the circular-flow diagram shown, boxes A and B represent
options: households and firms.
government and the foreign sector.
the goods and services market and the factors of production market.
households and government.
questions.correctAnswer: households and firms.

questions.question: In the circular-flow diagram shown, boxes C and D represent
options: households and firms.
the goods and services market and the financial market.
the goods and services market and the factors of production market.
households and government.
questions.correctAnswer: the goods and services market and the factors of production market.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about production possibilities frontiers is correct?
options: An economy can produce only on its production possibilities frontier.
More than one point on a production possibilities frontier can be produced if there is an increase in available resources.
An economy can produce at any point on or inside the production possibilities frontier.
An economy can produce at any point outside the production possibilities frontier.
questions.correctAnswer: An economy can produce at any point on or inside the production possibilities frontier.

questions.question: A point that is on a production possibilities frontier represents a combination of two goods that an economy
options: will never be able to produce.
can produce using all available resources and technology.
can produce using some of its resources and technology.
may be able to produce sometime in the future with additional resources and technology.
questions.correctAnswer: can produce using all available resources and technology.

questions.question: Macroeconomics is concerned primarily with the
options: way things are produced.
prices of particular goods and services.
behavior of consumers.
study of economy-wide phenomena.
questions.correctAnswer: study of economy-wide phenomena.

questions.question: “The government should use any budget surplus to reduce taxes instead of paying down the national debt” is an example of
options: a positive economic statement.
sound fiscal management.
a normative economic statement.
a welfare statement.
questions.correctAnswer: a normative economic statement.

questions.question: Economists from the Treasury Department provide
options: the annual Economic Report of the President.
advice on tax policy to the President.
enforcement of the U. S. Antitrust laws.
Congress with the annual budget.
questions.correctAnswer: advice on tax policy to the President.

questions.question: If labor in Mexico is less productive than labor in the United States in all areas of production,
options: neither nation can benefit from trade.
Mexico can benefit from trade but the United States cannot.
both nations can benefit from trade.
Mexico will not have a comparative advantage in any good.
questions.correctAnswer: both nations can benefit from trade.

questions.question: The principle of comparative advantage was developed by
options: Adam Smith.
Harry Truman.
David Ricardo.
John Maynard Keynes.
questions.correctAnswer: David Ricardo.
